pgTitle: List of Irish-American Medal of Honor recipients

rows.text: Served on board the USS Crusader and the USS Keokuk during various actions of those vessels.
Gallantry in various actions during the rebellion.
On board the U.S.S. Minnesota in action during the assault on Fort Fisher, 15 January 1865.

Removed severely wounded officers and soldiers from the field while under a heavy fire from the enemy, exposing himself beyond the call of duty, thus furnishing an example of most distinguished gallantry.

Error: 1863 May 2 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Volunteered on a dangerous service and brought in valuable information.
Error: 1864 Jun 17 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Rescued a wounded comrade who lay exposed to the enemy's fire, receiving a severe wound in the effort.
Error: 1864 Jul 20 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Error: 1863 May 22 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Gallantry in the charge of the "volunteer storming party."
Error: 1864 May 12 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Capture of flag, seizing it as his regiment advanced over the enemy's works. He received a bullet wound in the chest while capturing flag.
Error: 1864 May 6 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
At the risk of his own life went back while the rebels were still firing and, finding Col. Wheelock unable to move, alone and unaided, carried him off the field of battle.
Error: 1862 Sep 20 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Voluntarily attempted to spike a gun in the face of the enemy.
Error: 1865 Apr 9 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Gallantry in the charge of the "volunteer storming party."
Error: 1863 Jul 2 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Error: 1864 October 31 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Served on board the U.S.S. Commodore Hull at the capture of Plymouth, 31 October 1864
Gallantly led his regiment in battle at a critical moment.
Error: 1864 December 23 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Conlan served on board the U.S.S. Agawam, as one of a volunteer crew of a powder boat which was exploded near Fort Fisher, 23 December 1864.
On board the U.S.S. Minnesota, in action during the assault on Fort Fisher, 15 January 1865.
Error: 1865 Apr 2 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Was one of a detachment of 20 picked artillerymen who voluntarily accompanied an infantry assaulting party, and who turned upon the enemy the guns captured in the assault.
Served on board the U.S.S. Cincinnati during the attack on the Vicksburg batteries and at the time of her sinking
Error: 1864 August 5 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
On board the U.S.S. Richmond in action at Mobile Bay on 5 August 1864
Voluntarily exposed himself to great danger by going to the fighting line there succoring the wounded and helpless and conducting them to the field hospital.
Error: 1863 Oct 12 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.

At the head of a detachment of his company dashed across an open field, exposed to a deadly fire from the enemy, and succeeded in dislodging them from an unoccupied house, which he and his comrades defended for several hours against repeated attacks, thus preventing the enemy from flanking the position of the Union forces.
Error: 1864 August 5 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.

As a landsman on board the U.S.S. Lackawanna, Dougherty acted gallantly without orders when the powder box at his gun was disabled under the heavy enemy fire, and maintained a supply of powder throughout the prolonged action. Dougherty also aided in the attacks on Fort Morgan and in the capture of the prize ram Tennessee.
During a rout and while under orders to retreat seized the colors, rallied the men, and drove the enemy back.

Error: 1862 May This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input. and Error: 1864 Jun This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Error: 1864 August 5 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
As captain of the No. 1 gun on board the flagship U.S.S. Hartford, during action against rebel gunboats, the ram Tennessee and Fort Morgan in Mobile Bay, 5 August 1864.
Error: 1864 Sep 29 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Gallantry in the charge on the enemy's works: rushing forward with the colors and calling upon the men to follow him; was severely wounded.
Error: 1863 Feb 15 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Was one of a detachment of 16 men who heroically defended a wagon train against the attack of 125 cavalry, repulsed the attack and saved the train.
Error: 1863 Jul 3 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Capture of flag of 52d North Carolina Infantry (C.S.A.).
Error: 1863 May 22 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Gallantry in the charge of the "volunteer storming party."
"[D]istinguished himself by a display of coolness when he participated in landing and spiking a 9-inch gun while under a devastating fire from enemy musketry."
While acting as an aide and carrying an important message, was severely wounded and his horse killed but delivered the order and rejoined his general.
On board the U.S.S. Brooklyn during action against rebel forts and gunboats and with the ram Tennessee in Mobile Bay, 5 August 1864
After being most desperately wounded, he captured the colors of the 8th Virginia Cavalry (C.S.A.).
Error: 1863 Jul 2 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Held his ground with the battery after the other batteries had fallen back until compelled to draw his piece off by hand; he was severely wounded.
Served on board the U.S.S. Marmora off Yazoo City, Miss., 5 March 1864. Landed ashore with his howitzer gun and crew in the midst of battle and contributed to the turning back of the enemy.
On board the U.S.S. Rhode Island which was engaged in rescuing men from the stricken Monitor in Mobile Bay, on 30 December 1862.
Gallantry in the recapture of 4 guns and the capture of 2 additional guns from the enemy; also the capture of a number of prisoners.
Assisted a wounded comrade to the riverbank and, under heavy fire of the enemy, swam with him across a branch of the Potomac to the Union lines.
Capture of flag of 8th Mississippi Infantry (C.S.A.)

Despite damage to his ship and the loss of several men on board as enemy fire raked her decks, Sgt. Martin fought his gun with skill and courage throughout the furious 2 hour battle which resulted in the surrender of the rebel ram Tennessee and in the damaging and destruction of batteries at Fort Morgan.
Error: 1863 May 3 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Went 250 yards in front of his regiment toward the position of the enemy and under fire brought within the lines a wounded and unconscious comrade.
In a hand-to-hand encounter with the enemy captured a flag, was wounded in the act, but continued on duty until he received a second wound.
Error: 1863 May 27 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Serving on board the USS Cincinnati during the attack on the Vicksburg batteries and at the time of her sinking, 27 May 1863.
Served on board the USS Fort Hindman during the engagement near Harrisonburg, La., 2 March 1864.
Error: 1864 Jun 17 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Recapture of colors of 7th New York Heavy Artillery.

Serving as coxswain on board the USS Carondelet, Morrison was commended for meritorious conduct in general and especially for his heroic conduct and his inspiring example to the crew in the engagement with the rebel ram Arkansas, Yazoo River, 15 July 1862.
In command of the picket line held the enemy in check all night to cover the retreat of the Army.
Although wounded three times, carried the colors throughout the conflict.
This officer, commanding the regiment, kept it on the field exposed to the fire of the enemy for 3 hours without being able to fire one shot in return because of the ammunition being exhausted.
For his actions while serving on board the USS Fort Henry, Crystal River, Fla., 15 June 1863.
Gallantly maintained the line of battle until ordered to fall back.
Error: 1863 Jul 3 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.

Taking up the colors where they had fallen, he rushed ahead of his regiment, close to the muzzles of the enemy's guns, and engaged in the desperate struggle in which the enemy was defeated, and though severely wounded, he held the colors until wounded a second time.
Error: 1864 November 28 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.

Served as coxswain on board the U.S. Sloop John Adams, Sullvan's Island Channel, 28 November 1864. Taking part in the boarding of the blockade runner Beatrice while under heavy enemy fire from Fort Moultrie, O'Brien, who was in charge of one of the boarding launches, carried out his duties with prompt and energetic conduct. This action resulted in the firing of the Beatrice and the capture of a quantity of supplies from her.
Error: 1865 Mar 2 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Capture of flag and of a Confederate officer with his horse and equipment
Error: 1864 Aug 5 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
On board the flagship USS Hartford, during successful attacks against Fort Morgan, rebel gunboats and the ram Tennessee in Mobile Bay on 5 August 1864.
Date and place of act not of record in War Department.
Gallantry in the charge of the "volunteer storming party"

Error: 1863 May 22 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input. and Error: 1864 Mar 14 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.

Voluntarily joined the color guard in the assault on the enemy's works when he saw indications of wavering and caused the colors of his regiment to be planted on the parapet. Voluntarily placed himself in the ranks of an assaulting column (being then on staff duty) and rode with it into the enemy's works, being the only mounted officer present, was twice wounded in battle.
Error: 1864 May 5 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Served as boatswain's mate on board the USS Signal, Red River, 5 May 1864.
Error: 1863 May 1 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Took up the colors from the hands of the color bearer who had been shot down and bore them through the remainder of the battle.
Seized the regimental flag upon the death of the standard bearer in a hand-to-hand fight and prevented it from falling into the hands of the enemy.
Seized the colors of his regiment, the color bearer having been shot down, and bore them to the front where both his arms were carried off by a shell.
Led his regiment on the enemy's battery, silenced the guns, held the position against overwhelming numbers, and covered the retreat of the 2d Army Corps.
On board the USS Minnesota in the assault on Fort Fisher, 15 January 1865.
On board the USS Oneida during action against rebel forts and gunboats and with the ram Tennessee in Mobile Bay, 5 August 1864.
With one companion, captured 14 Confederates in the severest part of the battle.
For assuming command of the brigade, rallying the troops, and remaining in command though wounded.
Served as second quartermaster on board the USS Kearsarge when she destroyed the Alabama off Cherbourg, France, 19 June 1864.
Error: 1864 December 2 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
On board the USS Agawam as one of a volunteer crew of a powder boat which was exploded near Fort Fisher, 2 December 1864.

Error: 1864 Jun 23 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input. – Error: 1864 Jun 25 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.

Served on board the USS Louisville during various actions of that vessel. During the engagements of the Louisville, Sullivan served as first captain of a 9inch gun and throughout his period of service was "especially commended for his attention to duty, bravery, and coolness in action."

Voluntarily took command of the 9th Massachusetts while adjutant, bravely fighting from 3 p.m. until dusk, rallying and re_forming the regiment under fire; twice picked up the regimental flag, the color bearer having been shot down, and placed it in worthy hands.
Recaptured the flag of the 15th New Jersey Infantry.
Capture of colors of 44th Georgia Infantry (C.S.A.).
Gallantry in the charge of the "volunteer storming party."
Error: 1864 Jul 30 This is not an acceptable date format. Please check the spelling, check the numbers and/or read the documentation at template for correct date input.
Bore off the regimental colors after the color sergeant had been wounded and the color corporal bearing the colors killed thereby saving the colors from capture.
Carried with others by hand a cannon up to and fired it through an embrasure of the enemy's works.
